title: Can a college hold my transcripts after bankruptcy.
question: I went to a college in the Winter of 2014 in California. I withdrew with what I thought was the right amount of time. I never got a notice from them about a balance. They had returned my student loans to the lender. I went to get my transcripts sent to a new college and they are saying i owe 1600. I filed Bankruptcy in December and had it Discharged in March. They are now saying it is 'student loan debt' so they can hold my transcripts. This doesn't seem right since the 'balance' is with the college, not my lender. Can they hold my transcripts for a discharged bankruptcy or no? They have been giving me the run around for a week and a half now, and have people 'reviewing' it but give me not ETA. Do i have case for action against the college or not?
answers: The first thing you should clarify is whether you owe the school tuition or student loans. I mean, did the school extend a loan to cover your tuition? Or is it just a balance of unpaid tuition? Generally speaking, student loans are not discharged in a Chapter 7 filing. You should check your schedules to see if you listed the tuition and the school as a creditor. If you did, then the debt is discharged. However, if you failed to even list the $1600, either because you did not know you owed the money or because you forgot, then the debt is still very much alive. If you used a lawyer's services for your bankruptcy proceedings, go talk to him, and he will be able to guide you. If you didn't have a lawyer, then you should definitely talk to a lawyer and present all the facts. Good luck!

You apparently have two issues. The first--preliminary--issue is that the school seems to be taking the position that the debt in question is a student loan. That is possible, the school is (would be) the collector for Federal Perkins Loans. The more dubious position is if the school had you sign some sort of promissory note regarding unpaid tuition. The note converts any debt owed to the school to a student loan. The status of those "springing student loan notes" is up in the air in bankruptcy. So, you need to obtain better clarification as to the nature of the debt your owe. If the school is collecting on a Federal Perkins Loans, then that is a non-dischargeable student loan and everything the school is doing is legit (except that as Ariel points out, FERPA kicks in to allow you to at least see your transcript).

The second issue, assuming you are right regarding the nature of the debt (that it is just unpaid tuition and therefore discharged in your BK), is the withholding of the transcript. Generally, the best approach here is to contact the school's legal department (assuming it has one). If the school doesn't have a legal department or general counsel that you can identify, then you may have a token case for a discharge injunction violation.

Filing a chapter 7 bankruptcy has no effect on your student loans, unless you also filed an adversary action in the bankruptcy court to discharge your student loans.

The real question is why does the college believe that you owe money for the semester when you withdrew and they "returned your student loans the the lender." That would seem to be an acknowledgment that you withdrew by the deadline and that you did not have to pay tuition for that period. So for them to now say that you owe for unpaid tuition? -- clearly a mistake, either computer, clerical or otherwise.

If the objective is to just get your transcript released, a lawsuit would not be the best way to go because it may take a very long time to even find someone to represent you. The best course of action at this point is to identify the people responsible for accounting and student financial aid, write them a letter with a history of this dispute, attach relevant documents, send it via certified mail, and follow up on a weekly basis. If that doesn't work, at least you will have a good paper trail.

Student loans generally are not dischargeable. However, if the school is claiming you owe them for a non-student loan debt, they should be aware of your BK. Look over your BK papers to confirm they are listed. If so, their debt is discharged and they cannot hold your transcripts "ransom". Keep up the pressure and keep a "paper trail" of your communications. Anything discussed on the phone should be followed up with a letter or email detailing the phone conversation. If you used a lawyer in your BK, request a letter be sent to the school. If no lawyer, you can easily find one by clicking the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer".

If I understand the facts correctly, the college was owed for tuition, but not on a student loan. If so, the tuition would have been discharged if you listed the subject college in schedule F of your schedules. As for the issue of the colleges refusal to provide a transcript: according to the Family Education Rights and Privacy ACT (FERPA) [20 USC 1232 G and 34 CFR 99] gives students the right to inspect and review their own education records. In particular the statute provides the college to provide the student with a copy of the education records. However, this copy does not need to be an official copy of the academic transcript with the registrars seal. The college is permitted to provide the student with an unofficial copy of an academic transcript.
